ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: By taking this course, I was exposed to the intersection between statistics and law and got to learn a lot about how the two can complement each other. In terms of skills, I learned how to be more clear and concise in my writing and how to always structure my argument so that it gives a direct answer to the posed question. I learned a lot about formulating a strong argument and understanding the core of a problem.
It was a nice intro to law and its intersection with Econ.

Gained an interesting insight into the intersection of Economics and Law, which is not a common field in Yale courses. It was fulfilling to learn how to write in a more legal style and hone skills in applying economic analysis of cases presented to us through the semester.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: One of the biggest strengths of the course are the homework assignments which encourage you to write in a very precise manner and pick your words very carefully. I really enjoyed hearing Prof. Jaynes' advice in class on how to write strong assignments and how to think about what exactly the question is asking. It was good that discussions were free and open to take any direction, but I also believe that they could have benefited from a little bit more structure.
This class was very chill, which was nice. The professor is more involved and engaging than in Econ 129 (if anyone took that class as well). The assignments were pretty fair.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely! You're provided a very interesting intersectionality between Constitutional law, economics, and discrimination legislation.

I would recommend this course to anyone interested in Law and who is looking for an Economics seminar that is not heavy on Econometrics. The course is heavily qualitative, but the topics and questions discussed are very engaging.

Yes, it's a really chill econ senior seminar. Also, the professor is pretty engaging and the notes have all of the info you need for class. It is a unique class because unlike other Econ classes with psets, this class is more discussion based which is quite awesome!
Yes, very engaging and stimulating senior seminar with a professor who is individually also a very interesting and kind person.
